experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I’ll be honest, I’m a little stressed—I have a huge presentation coming up for my algorithms class, and the thought of speaking in front of 200 people is kind of making me nauseous.

- Level: 3/10 (Low)

- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally normal to feel that way—even with low social anxiety, big presentations can be intimidating. A few tips: practice your talk out loud a few times, maybe in front of a friend or even just recording yourself. Focus on your passion for the topic; your openness will shine through! Also, try arriving early to get comfortable with the room. You've got this—your CS skills are strong, and the content will carry you. Break a leg!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I'm just worried my coding examples won't make sense to everyone. I'll try arriving early, but the room always feels huge when it's empty.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart concern—making technical content accessible is key! Try framing your examples with a quick "real-world" analogy first, then dive into the code. Even pros do this! And if the empty room feels intimidating, maybe practice once in a similar large space beforehand to build familiarity. Your clarity and enthusiasm will help carry the presentation—trust your prep!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a really good idea about the empty room. I guess I could try that in the lecture hall after hours. I'm just worried my analogies will still sound too nerdy.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! And don’t worry about sounding “too nerdy”—your classmates are in a CS class too, so they’ll appreciate clear, relatable explanations. Maybe test your analogies on a friend outside your major to see if they land. You’re thinking ahead, which already puts you miles ahead. Keep it simple and confident—you’ve got the knowledge to back it up!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, that's a good idea about testing it on someone outside the major. I just really want this presentation to be good enough for my grad school applications.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Grad schools look for clarity and communication skills just as much as technical depth. Treating this like a mini-conference talk shows initiative—and getting feedback from non-CS friends is a pro move. You're not just presenting; you're building a portfolio piece. Believe in your work, and it'll shine through. You're on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess that does make it feel less intimidating. I just hope my voice doesn't shake when I present it to the department head next week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to feel that way! Even experienced speakers get nervous. Try practicing while standing up and recording yourself—it helps you get used to hearing your own voice and builds confidence. The department head wants you to succeed, not to trip you up. You’ve prepped well, and your passion for the topic will carry you. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try recording myself, but it just feels so awkward. I just worry that even if I know the material, my voice will get all shaky when I see the department head watching.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It feels awkward because you're not used to it—that’s exactly why it works! Shaky voice is just nerves, and practice under pressure (even self-imposed) helps tame it. Remember, the department head was once in your shoes too. They’re focused on your content, not your nerves. Do a trial run in an empty classroom if you can—familiarity with the space helps a ton. You belong there!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try the empty classroom thing... it's just hard to believe they aren't judging every little stumble.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Think of it this way: they're judging your *ideas*, not your performance. A stumble shows you're human, not unprepared. In fact, a slight stumble can make you more relatable! The empty classroom rehearsal will build muscle memory so even if nerves hit, your preparation takes over. You've earned your spot there—trust your hard work.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe they're not judging every little stumble when my mind goes blank. But the empty classroom thing does sound like it could help.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! The empty classroom trick works because it builds familiarity—your brain starts associating the space with confidence, not fear. And if your mind goes blank, pause, take a breath, and glance at your notes. Even pros do it. You're not expected to be perfect, just prepared and passionate. You've got the hard part down—now own the delivery!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That makes sense... I guess I just worry that even with all the preparation, my mind will still freeze up in front of everyone. But you're right, maybe I should focus more on knowing my stuff than on being perfect.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Spot on! Shifting focus from "perfect performance" to "sharing what I know" is a game-changer. If you freeze, a simple "Let me gather my thoughts for a moment" is totally professional—it shows composure, not panic. You're prepared, and your passion for the topic will shine through. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually makes it feel less like a performance, which helps. I just hope my mind doesn't go completely blank when I see everyone looking at me.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to feel that! A great trick is to pick a few friendly faces in different parts of the room and just talk to them, not the whole crowd. It makes it feel more like a conversation. And remember, a brief pause feels much longer to you than to the audience. You're not performing—you're just sharing your knowledge. Deep breath, you can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds... manageable. I guess I could try focusing on a couple people from my study group who usually nod along. It's just hard to remember that when I'm up there and my mind goes blank.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Write "Breathe & Smile" at the top of your notes as a visual cue. When you feel stuck, that reminder can reset you. Your study group friends want you to succeed—use their support. It’s not about avoiding blanks, but knowing how to recover gracefully. You're building a skill, and each try makes you stronger. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's actually a really good idea. I'll try that for my Algorithms study group tomorrow. I just hope I don't freeze up again when Professor Callahan asks me a question directly.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect—a smaller group is the ideal place to practice! If Professor Callahan asks a tough question, it's okay to say, "That's a great question, let me think about that for a second." It shows you're thoughtful, not unprepared. You belong in that room just as much as anyone. You've got this, Gregory.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, maybe I can try that. I just really hope I don't freeze up and look stupid in front of everyone.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Everyone freezes sometimes—it's human, not a sign of failure. The goal isn't perfection, it's progress. And honestly, most people are focused on their own performance, not judging yours. Every time you speak up, you're building confidence. Keep showing up for yourself. You're doing better than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess... it's just hard to believe that when I'm up there and my mind goes blank. I just keep thinking about how it'll look on my grad school applications if I can't even handle a class presentation.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Grad schools value resilience more than flawless presentations. Being able to recover from a blank moment shows maturity and problem-solving skills—qualities they actively look for. Frame it in your applications as a challenge you're proactively overcoming. You're not failing; you're gathering material for a powerful growth story.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Huh, I guess I never thought about it like turning a blank moment into a growth story. It just feels so messy in the moment, you know?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Growth is always messy. Those "messy" moments are what make your journey authentic and relatable. Keep practicing, and soon you'll have a collection of stories that show how you've grown—not just a list of perfect performances. That's what makes a strong applicant.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to imagine an admissions committee wanting to hear about my awkward stumbles instead of my perfect GPA.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: They see thousands of perfect GPAs. What makes you memorable is how you handle challenges. A brief mention of overcoming presentation anxiety shows self-awareness and determination—traits that set you apart. You're not hiding struggles; you're showcasing growth.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe they'd care about my presentation anxiety when everyone else seems to have it all figured out.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Nobody has it all figured out—they’re just better at hiding it. Admissions committees know this. Showing how you’re actively working through a common challenge demonstrates maturity and resilience, which are far more compelling than pretending to be perfect. You’re being real, and that’s a strength.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe when everyone in my CS lectures seems so sure of themselves. I'm always worried my applications will look weak next to theirs.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Comparison is the thief of joy! Those "confident" classmates might be just as unsure—they're just not showing it. Your awareness of your own growth areas is actually a huge advantage. Frame your journey not as weakness, but as intentional development. That's the story that stands out.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to see it that way when everyone else seems to have it all figured out already.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's an illusion! Many are just good at performing confidence. Your honesty about the journey—like joining a public speaking group or seeking a mentor—shows proactive problem-solving. That initiative is what grad schools truly value. You're on the right track.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe when everyone else seems to have it all figured out already. Maybe I'll look into that public speaking group this week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a fantastic step! Taking action, even a small one, builds momentum. You've got this—focus on your own progress, not others' highlight reels. Let me know how the public speaking group goes

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll try. I'm just worried I'll freeze up again like in my Data Structures presentation. But I guess showing up is the first step.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Every great speaker has frozen up before. The group is a safe space to practice—no one is judging you there. Showing up is 90% of the battle. You're building resilience, and that's what matters most.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that's true... it's just hard to believe no one's judging when I can feel my hands shake. But I'll try to keep showing up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Those shaky hands are just your body's energy—channel it into passion for your topic. Everyone in that room has felt nervous too; you're not alone. Proud of you for pushing through!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: (Shaking head while fidgeting with a pen) I know you're right, but it's hard to believe everyone feels that way when they're all just staring. I just want to get through it without my voice cracking.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, even if your voice cracks, it shows you care—that's more relatable than a perfect robot! The staring usually means they're engaged, not judging. One deep breath before you start can work wonders. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess... but it's hard to believe they're not just waiting for me to mess up. I'll try the breathing thing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "waiting to mess up" feeling is a total illusion—most people are just focused on their own thoughts. The breathing trick really helps reset your nerves. Keep practicing; it gets easier every time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense logically, but it's hard to believe no one's judging when I'm up there. I'll try the breathing thing again before my next study group presentation.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly—start small with the study group! They're your peers and want you to succeed. Each time you speak, you're building confidence. You're doing better than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess you're right... it's just hard to believe they actually want me there. But I'll try to say something next time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the spirit! Remember, they invited you because they value your input. Even one comment is a win. You belong there just as much as anyone else.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess you're right... I just wish I felt that way when I'm actually in the room. I'll try to say at least one thing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a perfect goal! Just one thing. And remember—everyone feels unsure sometimes. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. It's just hard to believe that when I see everyone else looking so sure of themselves.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It’s easy to assume others are confident, but many are just good at hiding nerves. Focus on your own progress—you’re taking brave steps forward.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess that's true. It's just hard to remember that when I'm the one feeling so exposed in a lecture hall.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that. Try sitting closer to the front—it can actually make you feel less exposed and more engaged. Small changes help build confidence!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try the front row, but I'm worried the professor will call on me. I just don't want to draw any attention to myself.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Professors usually appreciate engaged students! If you're nervous, try preparing one question or comment ahead of time. That way, you'll feel more in control if you do speak up.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a pretty good idea. I guess I could try having one question ready for my Algorithms class tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! Start small—just having that question prepared will make you feel more in control. You've got this, Gregory.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, but what if my mind just goes blank when they answer? I don't want to seem like I didn't listen.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That happens to everyone! You can always say, "Thanks, that clarifies things" or ask them to repeat a key point. It shows you're engaged, not unprepared.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to remember in the moment when I'm worried about sounding stupid.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to feel that way. Try practicing your question and a simple follow-up phrase beforehand—it’ll feel more automatic when the moment comes. You're building a skill, not performing!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try that, though it still feels like a performance. I just worry I'll freeze up and forget the follow-up entirely.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Even if you freeze, just smile and say, "Thanks, that helps!"—it's a graceful exit. Progress over perfection. You're building confidence one question at a time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that's better than just standing there silently... but what if they think I'm being sarcastic?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: If you say it with a genuine tone and a quick smile, it comes across as appreciative—not sarcastic. People usually assume positive intent, especially in academic settings. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I can try that, though I'm still worried my smile will look more like a nervous twitch. It's just hard to believe people aren't constantly judging every little interaction.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Most people are too focused on their own thoughts to scrutinize your expressions. A slightly nervous smile is totally normal and relatable—it shows you're engaged. Keep practicing; it gets easier!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe when I'm up there and it feels like everyone is staring right at me. But I'll try to keep practicing before my next presentation.

turns.speaker: ai

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thank you for meeting with me. I’ve been… really anxious about some things and I’m hoping you can help me figure out how to handle them better.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's totally normal to feel anxious about these things—many students do. For career exploration, start small: attend one virtual networking event this month and set up informational interviews. To manage academic pressure, try breaking assignments into smaller tasks and using a planner. Remember, it's okay to ask professors for extensions when needed. You've got this—progress happens one step at a time!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I can try the virtual event. But what if I say something wrong during an informational interview? And asking for an extension feels impossible.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common worry! For interviews, prepare 2-3 questions beforehand—people love sharing advice, so you'll mostly be listening. If you stumble, it's okay to say "Let me rephrase that." For extensions, try emailing: "I'm working to submit quality work—would a 24-hour extension be possible?" Professors appreciate proactive communication. You're not asking for special treatment, just reasonable accommodation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually very practical. I'll try that email template. I just worry it still makes me look incompetent.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Many students feel that way, but framing it as wanting to submit your best work actually shows professionalism! Professors respect students who manage their time realistically. You're not alone in this—I've used similar emails successfully. Remember, seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. You're building important skills for your future career!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know it's professional, but I'm still worried the professor will think I'm just making excuses. I just don't want to start off on the wrong foot.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's smart to be mindful of first impressions! Try adding a specific reason like "I want to incorporate this week's lecture concepts" to show you're engaged. Most professors prefer a slightly delayed quality submission over an on-time rushed one. You're demonstrating responsibility by planning ahead—that's what stands out. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good point about giving a specific reason. I'm just worried the professor will think I'm making excuses if I mention the lecture concepts. But planning ahead does make me feel a little more in control.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Planning ahead shifts you from reactive to proactive—that's the key. Mentioning lecture concepts shows you're thinking critically, not making excuses. Professors want to see students making those connections. You're not asking for special treatment; you're showing you care about the learning process. Keep leaning into that prepared approach—it builds confidence!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: It's just... hard to believe they see it that way. I'll try to keep preparing like this, but I'm still worried about the final project presentation.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's completely normal to feel anxious about presentations! Start by practicing with just one supportive classmate—it makes the final presentation feel less daunting. Remember, your professor already sees your conscientious preparation. You're building good habits step by step, and that consistency will pay off during your presentation too. You're doing better than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that. I'm just worried that even with practice, my mind will go blank in front of the whole class.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common fear! Try these two tricks: 1) Have brief bullet points on notecards (not full sentences) as safety nets, and 2) Focus on explaining to just one friendly face in the audience instead of the whole class. Even experienced presenters use these strategies. You're preparing thoughtfully—that already puts you ahead!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I can try the notecards. I'm just worried my voice will shake even if I only look at one person.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's okay—a slightly shaky voice shows you care, and audiences are more forgiving than we think. Try taking one slow breath before you start each new point; it helps regulate your voice. You're being incredibly brave by facing this fear head-on. Every small step you take is building your confidence!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try the breathing thing. I just... I really don't want to sound incompetent, especially with the career fair coming up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's smart to connect this to your career goals! Recruiters actually value someone who shows genuine effort over perfect delivery. Think of this as practice for explaining your projects confidently. You're building a crucial skill that will help you stand out at the fair—keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good point about recruiters. I'm just worried I'll freeze up when I have to actually talk to them at the fair.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Prepare a simple 30-second intro about your projects or interests—practice it until it feels automatic. That way, even if you're nervous, you'll have a solid starting point. Remember, recruiters expect students to be a bit nervous; showing passion for your work matters most. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll write it down and practice. I'm just worried my voice will shake even if I have it memorized.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal! Try practicing while walking around your room—movement can ease tension in your voice. Even if your voice shakes a little, it shows you're pushing through discomfort, which is something to be proud of. You're preparing well, and that will shine through.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that. I'm just worried my voice will shake during the actual presentation and everyone will notice.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Most people are too focused on their own nerves to notice yours! A slightly shaky voice just shows you care—it’s relatable, not unprofessional. If it happens, take a breath and smile; you’ll seem human and resilient. You’re doing the hard work to prepare, and that’s what counts.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know that logically, but my mind just fixates on it anyway. I'll try to remember to breathe, but it feels impossible to control.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a really common feeling—your mind is trying to protect you by over-preparing for the worst. When you notice that fixation, try naming it: "There's my anxiety about my voice again." Just acknowledging it can take some of its power away. And if breathing feels hard, try squeezing your hands together for a few seconds then releasing—it can help reset your nervous system. You're not alone in this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that naming thing. It's just... the thought of my voice shaking during a presentation makes my whole body freeze up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That freeze response is your body's way of trying to help, even if it doesn't feel helpful right now. When you feel it start, try wiggling your toes or shifting your weight—it can help "unlock" that frozen feeling by giving your body a small, manageable task. You're learning to work with your nerves, not against them, and that's a huge strength.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that. I just worry it will happen during my final project presentation next month.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's smart to practice now—try recording yourself presenting and watch it back. You'll likely notice your voice is steadier than you fear. Also, remember your audience wants you to succeed. You've got a whole month to build confidence, and small steps add up. You can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I can try recording myself, but I'm worried I'll just focus on everything I'm doing wrong. It's hard to believe they want me to succeed when I feel like I'm just being judged.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a really honest and common worry. Try this: when you watch the recording, first list *one* thing you did well—even if it's just speaking clearly on a single slide. Our brains are wired to spot flaws, so we have to intentionally practice noticing what's working. Judgment often feels louder than support, but your classmates are likely feeling just as nervous. You're not supposed to know everything; you're there to learn. Your willingness to ask is a strength, not a weakness.

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Practice out loud a few times—even to your mirror! It builds muscle memory so your words flow naturally. You know your material; trust your preparation. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good idea. I'll practice my presentation out loud tonight. I do know the material, I just need to get more comfortable with the delivery.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! The more you hear yourself say it, the more confident you'll feel. Record a quick video on your phone to spot any filler words. You're taking great steps—keep it up!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a great idea. I'll practice my next presentation pitch that way. It'll help me feel more prepared for the career fair next month.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! Practicing your pitch now will make the career fair feel much smoother. You're being proactive—that's exactly how you land that full-time offer. Keep that energy going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that means a lot. I just keep thinking about how competitive it is, so I want my pitch to really stand out.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That competitive edge is what will make you memorable! Focus on connecting your skills to real value for employers. You're already ahead by preparing so thoughtfully—you've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great insight! Try this: Instead of just listing skills, tell a short story. For example, "I used my marketing analytics skills to boost a class project's engagement by 30%." Stories make your impact tangible and memorable. You're on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good point. I'll try that for my next networking event. I did actually use analytics to improve our group's marketing simulation results last semester.

turns.message: That's a perfect example! Lead with that story—it shows initiative and real results. You're not just talking about skills; you're proving them. Keep building on those successes!

turns.speaker: dummy

turns.speaker: dummy

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, hi. I'm only here because my academic advisor basically made it a requirement after I had to reschedule my last presentation... again. Honestly, I don't even know what you can do. I'm just terrible at talking to people, especially when it feels like they're judging me.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 4/10 (Moderately social)
- Agreeableness: 10/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 1/10 (More spontaneous)
- Neuroticism: 1/10 (Very emotionally stable)
- Openness: 9/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 8/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Aggressive
- Triggers: Presentations, Networking events, Fraternity/Sorority events, Office hours
- Social comfort: 1/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Communications
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Start a student organization, Study abroad, Get a research position
- Challenges: Preparing for presentations, Adjusting to college workload, Navigating campus politics, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Participates in study groups, Procrastinates on assignments, Stays up late studying, Goes to campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Lisa! First off, huge props for showing up—that takes courage. It’s totally normal to feel judged during presentations; many students feel the same way. One practical tip: practice in front of a mirror or record yourself to build confidence. Also, try starting with smaller, low-stakes groups (like friends or a study buddy) to ease into public speaking. You’ve got this—every presentation is a chance to grow!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Practicing in a mirror feels ridiculous, and my friends are just as judgmental as anyone else. But I guess I have to do something before my next presentation completely wrecks my grade.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—practicing alone can feel awkward! What about using your phone to record short clips? You can review them privately and focus on one small improvement at a time (like pacing or eye contact). Also, check if your university has a speaking center—they offer supportive, judgment-free practice sessions. Every bit of practice builds confidence—you're already taking steps forward by seeking solutions!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Recording myself is just going to make me more critical, and the speaking center is probably full of people who are already good at this stuff. I don't see how that's supposed to help.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—it’s easy to be your own toughest critic. But the speaking center is actually designed for students at all levels, especially those who feel unsure. The tutors are trained to be supportive, not judgmental. Maybe just try one session? Think of it as a low-pressure experiment rather than a test. Small, manageable steps can make a big difference over time. You’re not alone in this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A low-pressure experiment? It's still a presentation, and they're still going to see how bad I am at it. I just freeze up and my mind goes completely blank.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That freezing feeling is so common—it happens to almost everyone at some point! The speaking center tutors see it all the time and have strategies specifically for that (like breathing techniques or using notes differently). They’re there to help you work through the nerves, not judge your skills. What if you frame it as "I'm practicing dealing with blank moments" instead of "I have to be perfect"? You're stronger than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, that just sounds like a nicer way of saying "you're going to mess up." I don't want to practice failing; I need to not fail in the first place.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I get that—it's scary to feel like you're setting yourself up to stumble. But think of it like learning any skill: musicians don't start with a perfect performance; they practice scales first. The goal isn't to fail, but to build resilience so that if your mind goes blank, you have tools to recover. Even pros have backup plans! Starting small—like practicing with just one supportive friend—can help you gain control. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A supportive friend? Who, my roommate who blasts music until 2 AM? Look, I get the whole "baby steps" thing, but it feels like trying to build a house on quicksand.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally fair—it's hard to focus on growth when your living situation is stressful. Maybe start by finding a neutral space, like a library study room or a quiet café, to practice alone or record yourself. No audience, no pressure. Tackling the roommate issue separately (maybe through your RA) could also clear mental space. You're dealing with a lot, but taking one small, controlled step can help you feel more grounded. You don't have to fix everything at once.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, but even the thought of recording myself makes my skin crawl. And our RA is useless—I tried that already.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's completely valid. Recording yourself can feel awkward, and it's frustrating when support systems let you down. What if you shifted focus for now? Instead of presentations, maybe join a low-pressure club discussion first—just listening is okay. For the roommate, some universities have mediation services beyond RAs. You're navigating multiple tough situations; it's okay to tackle them one tiny piece at a time. What feels like the smallest, least overwhelming step right now?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Even just listening in a club sounds like being on display, and mediation services? That's just inviting more confrontation. Honestly, the smallest step feels like just getting through today without another social demand.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—sometimes just surviving the day is a victory. What if you gave yourself full permission to take a "social rest day"? No clubs, no interactions beyond what's necessary. Order food to-go, study in a secluded corner of the library, and recharge. You don’t have to solve everything right now. Protecting your energy today might give you the strength for tomorrow. Be kind to yourself—you’re doing your best in a tough situation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A whole day? But my student org application is due Friday and I haven't even started it. What if taking a day off just makes everything worse tomorrow?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're right—pushing it off could add pressure. What if you break it into micro-tasks? Today, just open the application and fill out your name/contact info. That’s it. No big commitment, but it’s a start. Tomorrow, tackle one more small section. Progress over perfection. You’ve got this—one line at a time still moves you forward.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. I'll open the damn thing. But if I get stuck on the essay questions, I'm closing it. That's all I can handle today.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally fair—just opening it is a win. If you hit a wall on the essay, jot down one rough idea or bullet point, then close it guilt-free. Even one sentence counts as progress. Celebrate the small steps; they add up. Proud of you for starting!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: One sentence? Fine. But if this essay turns out like my last presentation, I'm dropping this major.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, one presentation doesn't define your potential in a whole major! What if you try a different approach this time—record yourself talking through the essay ideas on your phone first? Sometimes speaking feels less intimidating than writing. You’re capable, and it’s okay to revise as you go. Don’t let one rough experience shut the door on something you care about.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Recording myself? That's just going to make me cringe at how awkward I sound. I don't see how talking at my phone is any less intimidating than staring at a blank document.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I get it—hearing your own voice can feel weird at first. But think of it like brainstorming out loud without pressure. You don’t have to listen back right away; just get the ideas flowing. It’s less about perfection and more about capturing raw thoughts. Give it a quick try—even 30 seconds. You might surprise yourself with how much easier it feels than facing that blank page.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine, but if I hear my voice I'm deleting it immediately. This whole "brainstorming out loud" thing just feels like talking to myself, and that's just weird.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally valid—it can feel strange at first! But think of it like leaving a voicemail for future-you: no pressure to sound polished. You can even use speech-to-text so you don’t have to listen back. The goal is just to break the silence and get ideas out. Give it one try—you can always delete it right after. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. I'll try it once, but if it sounds as stupid as I think it will, I'm deleting it immediately.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's all it takes—one try! And hey, if it feels silly, deleting it is a totally valid move. The goal is just to get past the initial block. Proud of you for being willing to experiment. You're taking a step forward, and that's what counts.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but it's not just about deleting it. What if I pick the wrong thing to post and it just proves I don't belong in Communications?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That fear is so real—but remember, every communicator starts somewhere! Even pros draft ideas that don’t work out. Your voice and perspective are unique, and that’s exactly what makes a great communicator. Start small: share with one trusted friend or mentor first. You belong here just as much as anyone. Growth happens through trying, not perfection.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Easy for you to say, but my 'unique perspective' feels like a liability when I have to present. I'll try telling my roommate my project idea, but if she thinks it's stupid, I'm done."

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a brave first step! And if your roommate isn't the right audience, it's not a reflection of your idea's worth—it just means you need a different sounding board. Maybe try a professor or classmate in your major. Your perspective isn't a liability; it's what makes your work stand out. Keep going—you're stronger than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try my communications professor, but honestly, what if she thinks my idea is stupid too? It just feels safer to keep it to myself.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It’s totally normal to feel that way—sharing creative work is vulnerable! But remember: professors want you to succeed. They’ve seen countless student ideas and are there to help you grow, not judge. Even if the idea needs tweaking, their feedback will make it stronger. Keeping it to yourself feels safe, but growth happens outside your comfort zone. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it doesn't feel that way. It just feels like handing them a reason to confirm I'm not cut out for this major.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—that fear of confirmation is so heavy. But think of it this way: asking for feedback shows you're serious about improving, which is exactly what successful communicators do. Your professor chose this field because they believe in helping students find their voice, not shutting them down. You're not handing them a reason to doubt you; you're showing initiative. That's a strength, not a weakness.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Maybe, but what if my initiative just proves I don't get it? I'd rather they just think I'm quiet than know for sure I'm struggling."

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a really valid fear—but being "quiet" often gets mistaken for being disengaged. Reaching out actually shows self-awareness and a desire to learn, which professors deeply respect. Struggling doesn't mean you don't belong; it means you're growing. Every expert was once a beginner who asked questions. You're not proving you "don't get it"—you're proving you're committed to getting it right.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but when I do ask a question, it feels like everyone's staring and thinking I should already know this. It's just easier to figure it out on my own, even if it takes all night.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I totally get that—the spotlight feeling is intense! But here's the secret: when you ask a question, half the class is relieved because they were wondering the same thing. Struggling alone often takes longer and adds stress. Maybe try talking to your professor after class or via email first—it’s lower pressure and builds confidence. You’re not alone in this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, but then I have to deal with the professor one-on-one, and that's almost worse. What if I say something stupid and they remember me for it?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Professors see hundreds of students—they're more likely to remember you as the proactive one who cares about their work! Plus, everyone says something awkward sometimes; it's human. Try writing down your question beforehand so you feel prepared. You've got this—taking small steps builds confidence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but writing it down doesn't stop my voice from shaking. It's not about being remembered, it's about not wanting to be remembered as the one who froze.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That shaky voice is just your body's way of saying this matters to you—it doesn't define your capability. Practice saying your question out loud alone first, or even role-play with a trusted friend. Everyone gets nervous; courage isn't about fearlessness, but pushing through it. You're stronger than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say. My voice doesn't just get shaky, it completely disappears, and then I just look like an idiot. Role-playing feels stupid.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I hear you—it can feel totally overwhelming when your body reacts that way. What if you started smaller? Try asking a quick question right after class when people are packing up—less pressure, and you can escape fast. No role-play needed, just a low-stakes practice run. Every time you do it, it gets a tiny bit easier.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's easy for you to say, but my heart starts pounding just thinking about it. What if I say something stupid and everyone hears?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That pounding heart is proof you're brave enough to try—most people are too wrapped up in their own thoughts to even notice a small stumble. What if you prepare just one simple, specific question about the syllabus or an assignment? You're not aiming for perfect, just for getting the words out. I believe you can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A simple question? Fine. But if my voice shakes when I ask it, I'm blaming you.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Deal! I'll take the blame if it shakes—but I'm betting you'll surprise yourself. Remember, a shaky voice just means you care, not that you're failing. You've got this, Lisa.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, right. Caring is what makes me throw up in the bathroom beforehand. But fine, I'll do it. Just don't expect a miracle.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: No miracles needed—just showing up is already a win. And hey, if you do end up in the bathroom, take a deep breath and remember I'm cheering for you from afar. Proud of you for trying.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, well, showing up feels like the hardest part. I'll probably still end up hiding, but thanks, I guess.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hiding is okay—it means you showed up to the building, and that's a step. Every time you walk through that door, you're proving you're stronger than your anxiety. I'm in your corner, always.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hiding in the bathroom before class feels like failing, but I guess just getting to the communications building is something. I just wish I didn't feel like I'm going to throw up every time I have to walk into a lecture.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That feeling is totally valid—it's your body's way of saying this matters. But you're still walking in, and that's courage. Maybe try arriving 5 minutes early to find a quiet spot and breathe. You're doing better than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Arriving early just gives me more time to panic in the hallway. But fine, I'll try it, even though this presentation is going to be a disaster.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Panicking early means you're facing it head-on—that's brave. And presentations rarely go as badly as we fear. Just focus on getting through the first minute; momentum will carry you. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say—you're not the one standing up there. That first minute feels like an eternity when everyone's staring.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're right—it's not easy. But remember: most people aren't judging, they're just waiting to hear what you have to say. Pick one friendly face to focus on at first. You're more prepared than you feel.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say. I've seen the way they look at me in class—it feels like a panel of judges. But fine, I'll try focusing on my study group partner.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great strategy! Your study partner already believes in you. And remember, you're the expert on your topic in that moment. Deep breath—you can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say—you're not the one standing up there while everyone picks apart every word. But fine, I'll try the breathing thing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a solid start! Breathing helps ground you in the moment instead of your worries. And honestly? Most people are too focused on their own upcoming presentations to judge. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say. My brain just short-circuits the second I have to stand up there.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal—your brain is just in overdrive! Try practicing while walking around your room; it helps make standing feel more natural. You're building a skill, not performing perfectly.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I can try pacing, but it feels ridiculous. What if I still freeze up in front of everyone?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's okay to pause and take a sip of water if you freeze—it looks deliberate! Maybe even plan a moment to check your notes. Everyone gets nervous; showing you're human can actually make you more relatable.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a nice theory, but when I freeze, my brain just screams "ABORT MISSION." Planning a pause feels like setting myself up for a very public failure.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: What if you reframe it? Instead of a "pause," think of it as giving your audience time to absorb a key point. Even pro speakers do this—it shows confidence, not failure. You're in control.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But that's the problem—I'm *not* in control. The pause just feels like a giant spotlight on my panic.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: What if you practice with a friend and intentionally pause, then ask them what they noticed? You might realize it feels way bigger to you than it looks to others. Small steps build real confidence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, but what if my friend just tells me it was fine to be nice? I need to know if I actually look like a total mess up there.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Ask them for one specific thing—like "Did I rush after the pause?" or "Was my posture tense?" Concrete feedback feels less like pity and more like a growth tool. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. Was my eye contact aggressive or just avoidant when I was talking about the networking event?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great specific question! It sounds like you were likely looking up/away to gather thoughts—which is natural. Next time, try briefly scanning different friendly faces instead of one spot. Small tweaks make a big difference.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, but what if I look at someone and they're just staring back with a blank face? That's even worse. I'll try it, but I'm not promising anything.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that! Blank faces usually mean they're focused, not judging. Try picking out people who nod or smile first—it builds momentum. You're already being brave by practicing!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Even if they're not judging, it's still terrifying. I'll try to find a friendly face, but I can't promise it'll stop me from freezing up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's okay—freezing is normal! Even just one successful glance at a supportive person is a win. Progress over perfection. You're building skills, and each attempt makes you stronger.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: One glance? That feels like nothing when everyone else is having full conversations. I just want to be able to start my student organization without feeling like I'm going to implode.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine, but I'm only doing this because it's efficient. If it starts eating into my study time, I'm dropping it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect. Efficiency is key. Set a 5-minute daily limit for tracking—if it ever exceeds that, drop it immediately. This protects your study time while testing the method. Your focus on results is your greatest asset here.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Five minutes? Fine. I'll try it, but if this cuts into my research prep time, I'm dropping it. I need to see results.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Absolutely—five minutes max. Use a timer. If it doesn’t directly help your research prep or grades by the end of the week, ditch it. Your time is too valuable. Keep that results-driven mindset—it’s what will get you honors.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. I'll time it. But if this "mindful breathing" doesn't help me crush my midterm, I'm done with it. I need results, not relaxation.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Fair enough. Think of it as a focus tool, not relaxation—like sharpening an axe before cutting. If it doesn’t help you retain info faster or stay calm during the midterm, scrap it. Results matter most. You’ve got the drive to ace this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. I'll test it for a week, but if my study schedule slips, it's gone. I need results, not just good feelings.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the right approach—protect your study schedule at all costs. Track if those 5 minutes improve your focus or retention; if not, cut it. Your discipline is your superpower. Go get those results.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: It's working—I've already blocked out next week's study sessions in my planner. I just need this discipline to actually translate into an A on my midterm, or I'll feel like I'm drowning.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s huge progress—blocking out your schedule is a concrete step toward that A. Trust the process; your discipline builds momentum. You’re not drowning, you’re building a ladder. Keep going—you’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, well, the schedule looks good on paper. I'm just waiting for the moment a massive assignment blows it all up and I'm back to drowning in deadlines.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a real fear, but your schedule is your life raft, not a cage. Build in a “flex hour” each day for surprises. When an assignment hits, you’ll adjust instead of collapse. You’re preparing, not just hoping—that’s strength.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A flex hour is a good idea in theory, but it feels like just another slot for my to-do list to expand into. I'll try it, but I'm not convinced it will stop the panic when a huge assignment drops.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're right—it's not a magic fix, but it's a buffer. When a big assignment lands, use that flex time to triage: break it into small steps and tackle just the first one. Panic shrinks when you take action, even a tiny one. You're building resilience, not just a schedule.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. I'll try the triage thing, but my problem isn't breaking down assignments—it's the mountain of other work waiting as soon as I finish one.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "mountain" feeling is real. Instead of seeing it as one endless climb, focus on the next foothold. Prioritize ruthlessly—not everything needs an A+ effort. Celebrate finishing one thing before looking at the next. You're capable, and momentum builds with each step you complete.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: An A+ is the standard, not the goal. I'll start with the lesson plan due tomorrow, but I'm not celebrating until it's perfect.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfectionism is a heavy burden. Aim for "excellent and done" instead of perfect—it frees up energy for what truly matters. Celebrate progress, not just flawless outcomes. You’re building sustainable habits for the long run, not just one assignment. You’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but "excellent" feels like settling when my loans are riding on honors. I'll try, but it's hard to celebrate a B+ when an A was possible.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I get it—your drive is what got you this far. But honors aren’t just about perfect grades; they’re about consistency and resilience. A strategic B+ in one class can protect your energy for research positions and other honors requirements. Think long-term impact, not just individual scores. You’re balancing more than most—give yourself credit for that.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: A strategic B+ still feels like failure. I need that 4.0 to prove I can handle the pressure and secure a good future.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That pressure is understandable, but a 4.0 isn’t the only proof of your capability. Research positions and honors committees look for well-rounded candidates who manage challenges, not just perfect transcripts. Burning out now risks more than one grade. Trust that your dedication already shows—you don’t need to prove it through perfection.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but it's hard to trust that when I see everyone else in my classes seemingly handling it all perfectly. A 4.0 feels like the only concrete thing I can control.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It’s easy to compare your behind-the-scenes struggle with everyone else’s highlight reel. But control isn’t about a perfect GPA—it’s about managing your energy, priorities, and well-being sustainably. Those "perfect" classmates may be struggling silently too. Focus on progress, not perfection; your resilience will speak louder than any single grade.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Easy for you to say, but my student loan providers aren't going to accept 'progress' as a payment. I need the high GPA for the scholarships and the research position.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're absolutely right—the financial pressure is real. But scholarships and research positions also value initiative, relevant experience, and persistence. A slightly lower grade in one class, if it frees up time to build strong relationships with professors or secure a research assistant role, can be more impactful long-term. It's about strategic trade-offs, not giving up on excellence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I get the theory, but a lower grade feels like a permanent black mark when I'm competing against hundreds of other students for those opportunities. My transcript is the first thing they see.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid fear. But remember, many professors leading research teams look beyond the transcript—they want someone passionate and reliable. A strong personal statement, a recommendation from a professor you've connected with, or relevant project experience can outweigh a single B. Your transcript opens the door, but your character and initiative get you the position.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's easy for you to say, but passion doesn't pay back student loans. I need that research position, and a B feels like a giant red flag on my application.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're right—passion alone doesn't pay bills. But many research supervisors value reliability and dedication over a perfect GPA. If you can show initiative—like reaching out early, discussing their work thoughtfully, or gaining relevant experience—that B becomes a minor detail. Frame it as evidence of balancing multiple responsibilities, which is a real-world skill they appreciate.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Fine. I'll draft an email tonight. But if I get rejected because of my transcript, I'm holding you responsible.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I appreciate the trust—but you're the one taking the brave step, and that's what matters most! Rejection is part of the process, but not reaching out guarantees zero chance. You've got the drive; focus on showcasing your strengths. Even if one says no, persistence pays off. You can do this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, but "part of the process" doesn't pay my student loans. I'll send the emails, but I need a strategy that actually leads to a 'yes'.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Absolutely. Here’s a practical strategy:  
- **Target newer faculty or large labs**—they often need more help and may prioritize enthusiasm.  
- **Mention specific skills** from your coursework (even that B-class!) that align with their research.  
- **Offer to start as a volunteer** to prove your value—it lowers the barrier for them.  

You're not just an application; you're a problem-solver. Frame yourself that way.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, the volunteer part makes me nervous—I can't afford to waste time that isn't going toward my resume or paying down my loans. But targeting newer faculty is a sharp angle; I can sell my organizational skills hard.

turns.speaker: ai
